Launch a Special Issue and Become the Lead Guest Editor
Mathematics and Computer Science
Vol.4, No.1, 2019
Dear Fowler, A; Khosmood, F
We have read your paper "The potential of young learners making games: An exploratory study" in "2018 IEEE GAMES, ENTERTAINMENT, MEDIA CONFERENCE (GEM)" and we think the paper is very interesting and relevant to the scope of Mathematics and Computer Science (http://www.mathcomputer.org).
Mathematics and Computer Science (MCS) (ISSN Print:2575-6036 ISSN Online: 2575-6028) is a well-known open-access journal which aims to provide a platform for researchers and practitioners to promote academic communications and the development of science and technology.
Scholars are welcomed to propose a special issue in their skilled fields. In consideration of your academic background and research achievements in mathematics and computer science, on behalf of the editorial board, we sincerely invite you to propose a special issue in the journal. On condition that the proposal is accepted, you will serve as the Lead Guest Editor.
How to Propose Special Issues:
  1. The special issue proposal form is available in the website below:
    http://www.mathcomputer.org/download/36Form.doc
  2. Send back the filled proposal form to us via this email directly
What are the Duties of a Lead Guest Editor
  1. Build a reviewer team of no less than five guest editors to undertake strict pre-check and peer-review procedures in order to guarantee the high quality of published manuscripts
  2. Make the decision on the rejection or acceptance of a paper
  3. Promote the special issue' visibility
  4. Invite authors to contribute papers to the special issue
What are Advantages of a Lead Guest Editor
  1. Keep current with the cutting-edge academic research
  2. Connect with excellent scientists worldwide
  3. Have a greater opportunity of being promoted to the Editor in Chief of the Journal
  4. Publish one paper without any charges in the special issue
  5. Receive a Certificate of Honor (PDF format)
  6. Get 1 hard copy of the special issue at no charge after the special issue has been completed successfully (upon request)
To learn more details about the special issue, please check out here: http://www.mathcomputer.org/si
Your research has left a deep impression on us and the abstract of which is listed as follow:
Title: The potential of young learners making games: An exploratory study
Abstract: This paper presents the preliminary results of a Summer Game Development Camp to improve perceptions and persistence of under-represented minorities in computer science (CS). The focus of the camp was to measure changes in the perceptions of and persistence with CS in girls aged between 9 and 11 years old. The game development camp consisted of four days of practical lessons on programming and game development. The camp concluded with a game jam on the final day. The participants used a tile-based free game development platform from Microsoft (Kodu Game Lab) to learn some programming concepts through making computer games. The preliminary results indicate that the children's perceptions of and persistence in CS are influenced by practical programming lessons and making games. The authors observed that a camp exclusively for girls could foster their confidence and capability in learning to program.
Cordially,
The Editorial Office of Mathematics and Computer Science
